newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran calls for OPEC Mideast sour crude benchmark.
newsitem.headline: Iran calls for OPEC Mideast sour crude benchmark.

text.p: Iran's Oil Minister Gholamreza Aghazadeh said on Thursday OPEC should provide international oil markets with one of its crudes as a benchmark for pricing oil exported from the Middle East.
"OPEC could offer one of its crudes as a benchmark for sour crudes to eliminate shortcomings of pricing oil in the Middle East," Aghazadeh told an energy conference here.
Large OPEC exports from the Middle East now are priced against the spot price of Dubai to Asian buyers and Brent for purchases in the Western market.
Output and trade in Dubai crudes have been drying up in recent years, making it less reliable as a benchmark for Asian sales.
World oil markets have not used Middle East OPEC crudes as benchmarks since the 11-member group eliminated official pricing in the early 1980s.
Iran, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Kuwait, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates produce more than 17 million barrels per day (bpd) -- nearly two-thirds of OPEC's 27 million bpd output.
